name: The Kraken
the-point: The legendary Kraken was likely just a Giant Squid that sailors saw and exaggerated.

name: Greek Gods
the-point: The Greek Gods were written to be flawed and messy to mirror human behavior.

name: Atlantis
the-point: Plato likely invented the story of Atlantis as a metaphor for a perfect society gone wrong.

name: Pandora's Box
the-point: In the original myth, it wasn't a box; it was a large storage jar called a 'pithos'.

name: Vampires
the-point: Vampire legends might have started from people misunderstanding how bodies decompose.

name: Ragnarok
the-point: In Norse mythology, the world doesn't just end at Ragnarok; it is reborn.

name: The Phoenix
the-point: The Phoenix is a universal symbol of rebirth found in Greek, Egyptian, and Chinese culture.

name: Sirens
the-point: In early Greek art, Sirens were half-bird, not half-fish.

name: Anubis
the-point: The Egyptian god Anubis has the head of a jackal because jackals were often seen in cemeteries.

name: Dragons
the-point: Why do almost all cultures (Chinese, European, Aztec) have dragon myths despite being oceans apart?

name: King Arthur
the-point: There is zero historical evidence that King Arthur actually existed; he is a composite of many leaders.

name: Medusa
the-point: Modern interpretations of Medusa often view her as a survivor rather than a monster.

name: The Minotaur
the-point: The Labyrinth might have been inspired by the complex floor plan of the Palace of Knossos.

name: Trickster Gods
the-point: Gods like Loki or Hermes were necessary in myths to explain why life is unpredictable.

name: The Yeti
the-point: Most 'Yeti' hair samples tested by DNA have turned out to belong to ancient species of bears.

name: Odin’s Eye
the-point: Odin traded his eye for wisdom, suggesting that true knowledge always requires a sacrifice.

name: The River Styx
the-point: In mythology, you had to pay a coin to cross the river to the afterlife, or be stuck as a ghost.

name: Fairies
the-point: In old folklore, fairies weren't cute; they were dangerous creatures that would kidnap people.

name: Thor’s Hammer
the-point: Mjölnir was famously short-handled because the trickster Loki sabotaged its creation.

name: El Dorado
the-point: El Dorado wasn't a city of gold; it was a ritual where a king covered himself in gold dust and dove into a lake.

name: The Trojan Horse
the-point: Some historians think the 'Horse' was actually a siege engine or a metaphor for an earthquake.

name: Selkies
the-point: Celtic mythology tells of Selkies—seals that can shed their skin to become human on land.

name: Achilles' Heel
the-point: The story of Achilles being dipped in the river Styx wasn't added until 1,000 years after the Iliad was written.

name: Baba Yaga
the-point: The Slavic witch Baba Yaga lives in a house that stands on giant chicken legs.

name: The Great Flood
the-point: Nearly every ancient culture has a story about a massive flood. Could it be a memory of the end of the Ice Age?
